content:
I agree, this has likely been the most complained-about feature since release of 102.

This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

More info: To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0=unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: (I creates a crude video that walks through the steps at 

   https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4  that demonstrates the following steps: 
   First, highlight a folder that you have set to unthreaded	    In the Message List view, in the column header, on the far right, open the options button that shows         context menu. :    At the very bottom is the option:    -> "Apply current view to..."    -> "Folder and its children..."    -> Hover over an account    -> In the next menu don't select a folder. Instead select the account name itself.  ALSO, for future installations of Thunderbird,  - install Thunderbird and exit prior to setting up accounts - create a simple text file with name of user.js with these lines:       // Set default threading to UNthreaded  ###   <== this line is optional, just for documentation      user_pref("mailnews.default_view_flags", 0); - copy the user.js file into the profile - now, when you start Thunderbird, unthreading will be the default. Problem solved.
creator: davidsk

content:
That's an extraordinarily detailed reply - many thanks. Mind you, it just sets the Unthreaded again - the problem is that when I've done that, it comes back by itself.

I personally am very comfortable with all the stuff you have provided, but to me it highlights one of today's biggest software problems - that of sloppy programming expecting users to become programmers to sort out program misbehaviour (microsoft Word comes to mind). This is totally the wrong approach - There is no way that Joe Bloggs and Granny Smith should have to go near this gobbledegook to use *any* app, let alone email.

Thanks again, David, a 'proper' reply !
creator: WellTired

content: You're welcome. I do make my thoughts known, but little chance for change. https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/discussions/stop-requiring-users-to-need-customizing-for-basic-services/td-p/41484

content: I don't know why Thunderbird is the culprit, as you also access the mail via other items. My suggestion is to first carefully review the setup for the account on each device. Are they all IMAP, or are some POP? And what are the specific settings for each? For example, one of those setups might be POP and set to download and delete after x days. That is a challenge seen regularly here where users access mail across more than one platform.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks for your reply - have checked and all are IMAP. Can't see anywhere to find a setting which would download and delete. Any further ideas please?
creator: sue.saunders35

content: I wish I did. Thunderbird has no facility to delete one account after two weeks. However, Thunderbird deletes junk mail after 14 days, so you may need to see if that is a possibility on one of your devices.
creator: davidsk

content: Was there a message about 'shared data'? Maybe if you post the settings for your SMTP server, it may offer some ideas.

content: I don't understand. You stated that Thunderbird marks it as junk. What else would you have it do?
creator: davidsk

content: Thunderbird is just a messenger; it sends messages from your IP address, using server configuration details that are provided by you, and reports messages from receiving servers back to you. I do recall a while back seeing a user being blacklisted from emails sent by Thunderbird, but that was due to an advertisement being embedded in messages by an anti-virus program. Thunderbird was just the unwitting carrier. With more information on the blacklist, someone here may have suggestions.
creator: davidsk

content: Was actually being caused by the Norton VPN.

content:
Seems that replacing the session.json file for the profile with the session.json.backup (essentially removing the reference to the previously open tab) has, at least for now, cleared up this issue.

Will be watching the system behavior. and report back if the situation recurs.

content: If I understand correctly, alias addresses rely on having a real address present. So, if you set up a real address, you could define filters that move mail sent to an alias to separate folders. And if you define identities for the aliases, you could set signature for each and compose, using the alias.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hello there We have read the message We try to help

The use of your antivirus program itself has and gives you different topics to use with your PC and/or other devices.

Using it with VPN off also gives you enough protection for safe surfing with Thunderbird.

In addition to the relevant security, if you are also interested in installing a separate VPN module, it is sometimes also possible to use it well on your Black Friday day.

If you have multiple security levels, try adjusting them.

There are also many paid VPN services that you can use for a week, for example.


Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: googlethunderbird
